contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences mean the same thing and emphasize that God created people in his own image. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: God created man ... he created him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lamech said the same thing twice for emphasis. His voice is a synecdoche for his whole person. Alternate translation: "listen carefully to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: listen to my voice ... listen to what I say

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lamech killed only one person. These two phrases mean the same thing and are repeated to emphasize the certainty of his action. Alternate translation: "a young man because he hurt me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: a man for wounding me, a young man for bruising me

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences mean the same thing. The second sentence explains the first and emphasizes that Noah obeyed God. These parallel sentences can be combined into one. Alternate translation: "So Noah did everything that God commanded him to do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: So Noah did this. According to all that God commanded him, so he did

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that all people spoke the same language. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: used one language and had the same words

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "the men who had promised to marry his daughters" explains what "sons-in-law" means here. Alternate translation: "the men who were going to marry his daughters" or "his daughters' fianc√©s" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: his sons-in-law, the men who had promised to marry his daughters

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "obeyed my voice" and "kept my instructions, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws" mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: "Abraham obeyed me and did everything I commanded him to do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Abraham obeyed my voice and kept my instructions, my commandments, my statutes, and my laws

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two sentences mean basically the same thing. The second explains the look that Jacob saw on Laban's face. Alternate translation: "Jacob noticed that Laban was no longer pleased with him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Jacob saw the look on Laban's face. He saw that his attitude toward him had changed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "What is my offense" and "What is my sin" mean basically the same thing. Jacob is asking Laban to tell him what he did wrong. Alternate translation: "What have I done wrong that you should pursue me like this?" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: What is my offense? What is my sin, that you have hotly pursued after me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both of these phrases mean basically the same thing. Joseph's brothers are using questions to mock Joseph. They can be written as statements. Alternate translation: "You will never be our king, and we will never bow down to you!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will you really reign over us? Will you actually rule over us?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joseph expresses an idea in two ways to emphasize its importance. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: all the abundance will be forgotten ... and the famine will devastate the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Joseph expresses an idea in two ways to emphasize its importance. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: The abundance will not be remembered ... because of the famine that will follow

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "we may live" and "not die" mean the same thing. Judah is emphasizing that they have to buy food in Egypt in order to survive. Alternate translation: "We will go now to Egypt and get grain so our whole family will live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: We will rise and go that we may live and not die, both we, you, and also our children

contextId.occurrenceNote: This repeats "you have done" for emphasis. Alternate translation: "What you have done is very evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: You have done evil, this thing that you have done

contextId.occurrenceNote: All 3 questions mean basically the same thing. They use these questions to emphasize that there is nothing they can say to explain what happened. Alternate translation: "We have nothing to say, my master. We cannot speak anything of value. We cannot justify ourselves." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What can we say to my master? What can we speak? Or how can we justify ourselves?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both sentences say the same thing for emphasis. Alternate translation: "Come and listen carefully to your father" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Assemble yourselves and listen, you sons of Jacob. Listen to Israel, your father

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrases "my firstborn, my might" and "the beginning of my strength" mean the same thing. The words "might" and "strength" stand for Jacob's ability to produce children. The words "firstborn" and "beginning" mean that Reuben is his first child. Alternate translation: "my first child after I became a man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: my firstborn, my might, and the beginning of my strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: you went up to your father's bed ... you went up to my couch

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Jacob combines them to emphasize that he does not want to participate in their wicked plans. Alternate translation: "I certainly will not join with them to make any plans" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: do not come into their council; do not join in their meetings

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two statements mean the same thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: your brothers will praise you ... Your father's sons will bow down before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements mean the same thing. It is implied that the vines are so full of grapes that the master does not mind that his donkey eats some of them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Binding his donkey ... to the choice vine

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements mean the same thing. It implies that there are so many grapes that they can wash their clothes in the juice. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: he has washed ... in the blood of grapes
